title: Witori
meta_title: Witori Volcano (Pago) — Eruption History & Facts | VolcanoAtlas
meta_description: Witori is a caldera volcano in New Britain, Papua New Guinea, with VEI 6 eruptions. Explore the Pago cone, eruption history, and hazards.

quick_answer.what: Witori is an active caldera volcano on the northern coast of New Britain island, Papua New Guinea, containing the historically active Pago cone.
quick_answer.status: Active — the Pago cone last erupted in May 2012. The caldera has produced multiple VEI 6 eruptions in prehistory.
quick_answer.famous_for: A series of catastrophic VEI 5–6 eruptions over the past 7,500 years that deposited thick pyroclastic sheets across New Britain, and the growth of the vigorous Pago cone within the caldera.
quick_answer.danger_level: High — a repeat of the prehistoric VEI 6 eruptions would devastate the densely populated northern New Britain coast.

key_facts_box.elevation: 724 m (2,375 ft) — caldera rim; Pago cone rises above the rim
key_facts_box.summit_crater: Caldera 5.5 × 7.5 km; Pago cone summit crater breached NW

overview.content: Witori is an active caldera volcano located on the northern coast of central New Britain island in Papua New Guinea, within the tectonically prolific Bismarck Volcanic Arc. The 5.5 × 7.5 km caldera contains the vigorously active Pago cone, which has grown to a height exceeding the caldera rim and is responsible for all historical eruptions at the complex. Witori ranks among the most explosively powerful volcanoes in the southwestern Pacific, having produced at least three VEI 6 eruptions over the past 6,000 years — at approximately 4000 BCE, 1370 BCE, and 710 CE — each of which generated massive dacitic pyroclastic flows and airfall deposits that blanketed central New Britain. These caldera-forming events deposited pyroclastic material extending more than 100 km from the source, making them comparable in scale to some of the largest Holocene eruptions globally. The dacitic composition of Witori's magma, enriched in silica, produces highly explosive eruptions when pressure builds sufficiently. In contrast, the younger Pago cone has produced less catastrophic but still significant eruptions in recent centuries, including a major dacitic lava flow event in 2002–2003 and a VEI 2 eruption in 2012. Witori's eruptive history places it alongside Rabaul, located 250 km to the northeast on the same island, as one of Papua New Guinea's most dangerous volcanic systems.

geology_and_formation.content: Witori sits within the Bismarck Volcanic Arc, generated by the northward subduction of the Solomon Sea Plate beneath the South Bismarck Plate. This subduction zone drives volcanism along the entire northern coast of New Britain, producing a chain of explosive stratovolcanoes and calderas including Rabaul, Ulawun, and Langila. The Witori caldera was formed through a series of at least five major collapse events between approximately 5600 and 1200 years ago, each associated with voluminous pyroclastic eruptions that stripped the caldera of material and allowed the roof to founder. The gently sloping outer flanks of the caldera are constructed primarily of dacitic pyroclastic-flow and airfall deposits from these catastrophic events — testifying to the enormous volumes of material ejected. Dacite, an intermediate-to-silicic volcanic rock, is characteristic of subduction zone magmatism where water-rich oceanic crust descends into the mantle, lowering the melting point and producing gas-charged, silica-enriched magma that erupts violently. The Buru caldera, a smaller subsidiary collapse structure, cuts the southwestern flank of the Witori complex, indicating that collapse events have occurred at multiple locations within the system. The Pago cone began growing inside the caldera less than 350 years ago and has rapidly built an edifice of dacitic lava flows and pyroclastic material, with at least ten distinct lava flows covering much of the caldera floor.

eruption_history_overview.content: Witori's 20 recorded eruptions span approximately 9,500 years, from ~7510 BCE to the most recent Pago eruption in 2012. The eruption record divides into two fundamentally different phases. The prehistoric phase (before ~1700 CE) is dominated by enormous caldera-forming eruptions, with three events reaching VEI 6 and two reaching VEI 5 — an extraordinary concentration of high-magnitude volcanism for a single center. These eruptions produced pyroclastic flows that traveled tens of kilometers and deposited tephra layers used as stratigraphic markers across New Britain. The historical phase, beginning with the growth of the Pago cone approximately 350 years ago, has been characterized by smaller but still significant eruptions: dacitic lava effusion, Strombolian to Vulcanian explosions, and occasional pyroclastic flows from the intra-caldera cone. The 2002–2003 eruption of Pago was the most significant recent event, producing multiple dacitic lava flows that extended from the summit nearly to the northwestern caldera wall.

subsections.title: The ~4000 BCE Eruption — First Known VEI 6 Caldera Collapse
subsections.content: Approximately 6,000 years ago, Witori produced a colossal eruption reaching VEI 6, generating enormous volumes of dacitic pyroclastic flows and tephra that were deposited across a vast area of central New Britain. This eruption is believed to have been associated with one of the major caldera-collapse events that created the present 5.5 × 7.5 km depression. Pyroclastic-flow deposits from this event extend more than 100 km from the caldera, indicating eruption volumes in the range of 10–100 cubic kilometers of material — placing it among the largest Holocene eruptions in Melanesia. The event would have had devastating effects on any populations living in northern New Britain, though no archaeological evidence of human impact has been definitively linked to this specific eruption.

subsections.title: The ~1370 BCE Eruption — A Second VEI 6 Cataclysm
subsections.content: Roughly 3,400 years ago, Witori erupted again at VEI 6, producing another major caldera-forming event with massive pyroclastic flows and thick airfall deposits. This eruption occurred during a period when Melanesian populations had been established in the Bismarck Archipelago for thousands of years, and the widespread tephra layer from this event has been identified in archaeological sites across New Britain. Some researchers have suggested that the scale of these repeated catastrophic eruptions influenced settlement patterns and population movements in the region. The 1370 BCE eruption deposited a distinctive tephra layer that serves as a critical chronological marker for archaeologists working in the Bismarck Archipelago.

subsections.title: The ~710 CE Eruption — The Most Recent VEI 6 Event
subsections.content: The most recent VEI 6 eruption at Witori occurred around 710 CE, making it one of the largest volcanic events in the world during the first millennium. This eruption produced voluminous pyroclastic flows that swept across the caldera and down the outer flanks, depositing thick ignimbrite sheets across northern New Britain. Like the earlier VEI 6 events, this eruption was likely associated with further caldera subsidence. The 710 CE event is significant because it demonstrates that VEI 6 eruptions have recurred at Witori on a roughly millennial timescale — at approximately 4000 BCE, 1370 BCE, and 710 CE — raising the question of whether the system could produce another such eruption in the coming centuries.

subsections.title: The 2002–2003 Eruption — Pago's Major Lava Effusion
subsections.content: Beginning on August 3, 2002, the Pago cone within the Witori caldera produced a significant eruption that continued into 2003, reaching VEI 3. The eruption generated explosive activity from the summit and northwestern flank of Pago, accompanied by the effusion of dacitic lava flows. These viscous flows extended from the summit nearly to the northwestern caldera wall, representing the youngest of at least ten major lava flows that have been erupted from Pago since its formation roughly 350 years ago. The 2002–2003 eruption covered substantial portions of the caldera floor with fresh lava and demonstrated that Pago continues to be a vigorous and productive volcanic center capable of significant eruptions.

subsections.title: The 2012 Eruption — Most Recent Activity
subsections.content: On May 3, 2012, Pago produced a brief VEI 2 eruption, the most recent confirmed activity at the Witori complex. The eruption was relatively small by Pago's standards but served as a reminder that the intra-caldera cone remains active and capable of erupting with little warning. The eruption produced ash emissions and minor explosive activity typical of Pago's recent behavior pattern.

current_status_and_monitoring.content: The Pago cone within the Witori caldera has been quiet since the May 2012 eruption, though fumarolic activity and thermal emissions continue at the summit. The volcano is monitored by the Rabaul Volcanological Observatory (RVO), Papua New Guinea's primary volcanic monitoring agency, which operates seismic stations and conducts periodic surveillance of the complex. Satellite-based monitoring through thermal anomaly detection and InSAR (Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar) provides additional remote surveillance. Given Witori's extraordinary history of VEI 5–6 eruptions recurring on roughly millennial timescales, and with over 1,300 years having elapsed since the last VEI 6 event in ~710 CE, the system warrants close long-term monitoring. The more immediate concern, however, is the ongoing activity of the Pago cone, which has erupted multiple times in the past century and shows no signs of entering a prolonged dormancy.

hazards_and_risk_assessment.content: Witori presents a dual-scale hazard. At the smaller scale, eruptions from the Pago cone pose risks of pyroclastic flows, lava flows, ashfall, and ballistic projectiles within and immediately surrounding the caldera — hazards comparable to those at other active cones in Papua New Guinea. At the larger scale, a repeat of the VEI 5–6 caldera-forming eruptions that have occurred three times in the past 6,000 years would represent a catastrophic regional disaster. Such an eruption would generate pyroclastic flows traveling tens of kilometers across northern New Britain, deposit thick tephra layers over a vast area, and potentially trigger tsunami if pyroclastic flows entered the sea — similar to the hazards assessed for Rabaul's largest historical events. West New Britain Province has a population of approximately 100,000, concentrated in Kimbe and coastal towns that lie within the potential impact zone of large-scale pyroclastic flows. Evacuation would be extremely challenging given the limited road infrastructure and island geography. The recurrence interval of roughly 1,000–2,700 years between VEI 6 events does not allow precise forecasting, but it places Witori firmly among the highest-magnitude volcanic threats in the Pacific.

geography_and_physical_description.content: The Witori caldera measures 5.5 × 7.5 km and is situated on the northern coast of central New Britain, the largest island in the Bismarck Archipelago. The caldera's outer flanks slope gently, constructed of thick pyroclastic deposits from the prehistoric VEI 5–6 eruptions. Inside the caldera, the Pago cone rises as a prominent feature, having grown above the caldera rim since its formation roughly 350 years ago. A small summit crater on Pago is breached to the northwest. The caldera floor is largely covered by ten or more distinct dacitic lava flows erupted from Pago, the youngest dating to 2002–2003. The Buru caldera, a smaller collapse feature, is incised into the southwestern flank. The surrounding landscape is characterized by tropical rainforest at lower elevations, with the volcanic terrain supporting regrowth vegetation on younger deposits. The coastline to the north lies close to the caldera, meaning pyroclastic flows from major eruptions could reach the sea rapidly.

climate_and_global_impact.content: The VEI 6 eruptions at Witori in approximately 4000 BCE, 1370 BCE, and 710 CE were large enough to have injected significant quantities of sulfur dioxide and tephra into the upper atmosphere, potentially producing measurable hemispheric cooling effects. However, precise climate impacts from these events are difficult to isolate in paleoclimate records due to the presence of other large eruptions in similar time periods and the limited resolution of proxy records in the tropical Pacific. The 710 CE eruption, being the most recent VEI 6 event, may have contributed to climate anomalies recorded in ice cores and tree rings from the 8th century, though attribution remains uncertain. The smaller Pago cone eruptions of the historical period have had only localized atmospheric effects.

cultural_significance.content: Witori and its eruptions have profoundly shaped the human history of the Bismarck Archipelago. Tephra layers from the caldera's VEI 6 eruptions are critical stratigraphic markers used by archaeologists to date and correlate sites across New Britain and neighboring islands. The massive eruptions likely forced population displacements, abandonment of settlements, and disruption of trade networks among Melanesian communities. Oral traditions of the Nakanai and Baining peoples of New Britain include references to catastrophic volcanic events, though direct correlation with specific Witori eruptions is challenging. The younger Pago cone's eruptions have periodically displaced local communities from areas near the caldera.

visiting_and_tourism.content: Witori is not a conventional tourist destination. Access to the caldera requires travel through remote tropical terrain in West New Britain Province. The nearest town of Kimbe, the provincial capital, is served by flights from Port Moresby and Rabaul. From Kimbe, reaching the Witori caldera requires overland travel on limited roads and potentially jungle trekking. There is no established tourist infrastructure at the volcano. Visitors interested in the region's volcanism more typically visit Rabaul and its accessible Tavurvur cone at the eastern end of New Britain. Any approach to the active Pago cone should be undertaken only with local guides and awareness of current volcanic activity levels, as the cone can erupt with limited precursory warning.

nearby_volcanoes.content: Witori sits within the volcanically prolific Bismarck Arc along northern New Britain. To the northeast, Ulawun — Papua New Guinea's tallest volcano at 2,334 m — is one of the most active and dangerous volcanoes in the country, designated a Decade Volcano by the IAVCEI. Langila, another frequently active cone, lies to the northeast. At the far eastern end of New Britain, Rabaul caldera has produced its own VEI 6 eruption around 683 CE and remains one of the most active calderas in the Pacific. The concentration of large caldera systems along this single island makes New Britain one of the most volcanically hazardous regions on Earth.

etymology.content: The name Witori derives from local Melanesian language. The intra-caldera Pago cone takes its name from a local settlement or geographic feature. In some older literature, the complex is referred to simply as the Pago volcanic complex, with Witori referring specifically to the outer caldera.

eruption_timeline.label: Most recent VEI 6 — massive pyroclastic flows
Pago cone — major dacitic lava flows

eruptions_per_century.note: Includes three VEI 6 and two VEI 5 events

facts: Witori has produced at least three VEI 6 eruptions in the past 6,000 years — approximately 4000 BCE, 1370 BCE, and 710 CE — making it one of the most explosively productive calderas in the Holocene.
Pyroclastic-flow deposits from Witori's largest eruptions extend more than 100 km from the caldera, covering vast areas of central New Britain.
The Pago cone inside the caldera is less than 350 years old but has already grown above the caldera rim and produced at least ten distinct dacitic lava flows covering most of the caldera floor.
The 5.5 × 7.5 km Witori caldera was formed by at least five major collapse events between approximately 5600 and 1200 years ago.
Witori's VEI 6 eruptions recur on a roughly millennial timescale, with the most recent occurring over 1,300 years ago — placing the system within its historical recurrence window.
The Buru caldera, a smaller collapse structure, cuts into the southwestern flank of the Witori complex, indicating multiple collapse centers.
New Britain hosts both Witori and Rabaul — two caldera systems that have each produced VEI 6 eruptions within the past 1,400 years.
Tephra layers from Witori's massive eruptions are used as key chronological markers by archaeologists studying human settlement patterns across the Bismarck Archipelago.
The 2002–2003 eruption of Pago produced dacitic lava flows that extended from the summit nearly to the northwestern caldera wall.
Witori's dacitic magma composition makes it significantly more explosive than the basaltic volcanoes that dominate many oceanic island arcs.

faqs.question: Is Witori an active volcano?
faqs.answer: Yes, Witori is classified as an active volcano. The Pago cone within the caldera last erupted in May 2012, and has erupted multiple times in the past century. The larger Witori caldera system has produced some of the most powerful eruptions in the Pacific over the past 6,000 years, including three events reaching VEI 6. Fumarolic activity continues at the Pago summit, and volcanologists consider the system capable of future eruptions ranging from moderate cone-building events to potentially catastrophic caldera-forming eruptions.

faqs.question: What is the relationship between Witori and Pago?
faqs.answer: Pago is a young volcanic cone that has grown inside the much older and larger Witori caldera. The Witori caldera, measuring 5.5 × 7.5 km, was formed by a series of massive collapse events between approximately 5600 and 1200 years ago. Pago began growing within this caldera less than 350 years ago and has since risen above the caldera rim. All historical eruptions at the complex have originated from the Pago cone, while the prehistoric VEI 5–6 eruptions were caldera-scale events involving the broader Witori system.

faqs.question: How big were Witori's largest eruptions?
faqs.answer: Witori has produced at least three eruptions reaching VEI 6 on the Volcanic Explosivity Index, at approximately 4000 BCE, 1370 BCE, and 710 CE. VEI 6 eruptions eject 10–100 cubic kilometers of material and are classified as 'colossal.' For comparison, the 1991 eruption of Mount Pinatubo — which affected global climate — was a VEI 6 event. Witori's eruptions generated massive pyroclastic flows and deposited tephra layers extending over 100 km from the caldera.

faqs.question: When did Witori last erupt?
faqs.answer: The most recent eruption at the Witori complex occurred on May 3, 2012, when the intra-caldera Pago cone produced a VEI 2 eruption with ash emissions and minor explosive activity. The previous eruption at Pago, in 2002–2003, was more significant at VEI 3 and produced dacitic lava flows that covered portions of the caldera floor. The most recent large-scale caldera eruption was the VEI 6 event around 710 CE, over 1,300 years ago.

faqs.question: Could Witori produce another VEI 6 eruption?
faqs.answer: Yes, volcanologists consider another large-scale eruption at Witori possible. The caldera has produced VEI 6 eruptions at intervals of roughly 1,000 to 2,700 years, and over 1,300 years have elapsed since the last such event around 710 CE. While the current Pago cone activity represents a much smaller scale of volcanism, the underlying magma system that produced the caldera-forming eruptions may still be capable of generating large volumes of dacitic magma. Predicting the timing of such events remains impossible with current technology.

faqs.question: Where is Witori located?
faqs.answer: Witori is located on the northern coast of central New Britain island in Papua New Guinea, within the Bismarck Archipelago. The caldera sits at coordinates 5.575°S, 150.516°E, approximately 50 km southwest of Kimbe, the capital of West New Britain Province. New Britain is the largest island in the Bismarck Archipelago and hosts numerous other active volcanoes along its northern coast, including Ulawun and Langila.

faqs.question: What type of volcano is Witori?
faqs.answer: Witori is a caldera volcano — a large collapse depression formed when massive eruptions emptied an underlying magma chamber, causing the overlying rock to subside. The Witori caldera measures 5.5 × 7.5 km and was formed through at least five major collapse events. Inside this caldera sits the Pago cone, a younger composite cone that has been the source of all historical eruptions. The volcanic complex is part of the Bismarck Volcanic Arc, generated by subduction of the Solomon Sea Plate beneath the South Bismarck Plate.

schema_data.name: Witori
schema_data.description: Active caldera volcano in New Britain, Papua New Guinea, with three VEI 6 eruptions in the past 6,000 years and an actively growing intra-caldera Pago cone
